Articles.Content: Should there be square parts? If not, why? If yes, why?
There are square parts. You've got all manner of cubic and rectangular structural bits like the micronode, struts and the RoveMate.

Edited because I apparently cannot read.

Edited May 2, 2014 by Vanamonde

If you mean instead of cylindrical parts, it's for a couple of reasons they're used instead of squared off parts:

Cylinders are the most efficient stackable shape in terms of volume per unit surface area. So a cylindrical tank of a given volume will be dimensionally smaller and have less structural mass than a cube- or rectangular prism-shaped one.

Cylinders are very strong in the axial direction. A flyweight aluminum beverage can can support the weight of a smallish adult. This is the usual direction that rockets endure loads.

Cylinders minimize frontal area and thus drag.

Edit: Vanamonde, SQUARE parts, not SPARE parts, lol.

Edited May 2, 2014 by Red Iron Crown
